bioghist.p: Ann Edwards was a native of Monroe County, Indiana. She worked as a bookkeeper for some years in a Bloomington clothing store. In 1944, she was a candidate for State Auditor on the Prohibition Party ticket.

Ann Edwards was active in the national activities of the Young Prohibitionists' Association. Interested also in various peace groups, she identified with the party's leftist wing which dominated the YPA. As a result of Stuart Hamblen's stridently anti-communist campaign of 1952, most of the YPA broke with the party to form Democracy Unlimited. Ann Edwards served as Secretary-Treasurer of Democracy Unlimited.

Unlike most of the dissidents, Edwards remained loyal to the Prohibition Party. She apparently had some foreknowledge and approval of Lowell Coate's unsuccessful coup d'Ã©tat of 1955, hoping to bring the dissidents back into a reconstituted party. By this time, Edwards had moved to St. Louis, Missouri, where she remained active in Prohibition Party activities until her death in late 1962.

scopecontent.p: The Ann Edwards collection consists of papers, letters and party records relating her activities with the Missouri Prohibition Party and the Greater St. Louis Prohibition Clubs. Included are correspondence, minutes of meetings, and printed material.
